question: What mineral has six-sided transparent crystals and can scratch glass?

content.source_1: Minerals that scratch common window glass have Mohs hardness greater than about 5.5; quartz (7) and beryl (7.5–8) both readily scratch glass.
content.source_2: Quartz commonly forms six-sided (hexagonal) prismatic crystals that can be transparent; it has Mohs hardness 7, no cleavage, and typically shows pyramidal terminations.
content.source_3: Beryl forms six-sided (hexagonal) prismatic crystals, often transparent (e.g., aquamarine, emerald); it has Mohs hardness 7.5–8, may show poor basal cleavage, and frequently exhibits flat basal terminations.
content.source_4: The specimen consists of transparent six-sided prismatic crystals that scratch a glass plate.
content.source_5: Quartz is one of Earth’s most abundant minerals and is the clear hexagonal crystal most commonly encountered in field collecting and teaching sets; beryl crystals are comparatively rare.
content.source_6: The crystals show flat, pinacoidal terminations and faint basal cleavage traces on end faces rather than pyramidal tips.
